vscode-containers.debug.containerName: Name of the container used for debugging.
vscode-containers.debug.dockerServerRead: Options for launching a browser to the container. Similar to serverReadyAction, but replaces container ports with host ports.
The action to take when the pattern is found.
The container name to match the host port.
The regex pattern to look for in Debug console output.
The root folder from which web pages are served.
vscode-containers.debug.removeContainerA: Whether to remove the debug container after debugging.
vscode-containers.debug.platform: The target platform for the application.
vscode-containers.debug.netCore.descript: Options for debugging .NET projects in containers.
vscode-containers.debug.node.description: Options for debugging Node.js projects in containers.
vscode-containers.debug.node.address: TCP/IP address of the debug port.
vscode-containers.debug.node.sourceMaps: Enable source maps by setting this to `true`.
vscode-containers.debug.node.outFiles: Array of glob patterns for locating generated JavaScript files.
vscode-containers.debug.node.autoAttachC: Track all subprocesses of debuggee and automatically attach to those that are launched in debug mode.
vscode-containers.debug.node.timeout: When restarting a session, give up after this number of milliseconds.
vscode-containers.debug.node.stopOnEntry: Break immediately when the program launches.
vscode-containers.debug.node.package: The path to the package.json for the application.
vscode-containers.debug.node.remoteRoot: Node's root directory within the container.
vscode-containers.debug.node.smartStep: Try to automatically step over code that doesn't map to source files.
vscode-containers.debug.node.skipFiles: Automatically skip files covered by these glob patterns.

vscode-containers.debug.python.args: Arguments passed to the Python app.
vscode-containers.debug.attach.container: The container name to attach to. If not specified, then user will be prompted to pick a container.
vscode-containers.debug.attach.processNa: The process name to attach to. If this is used, 'processId' should not be used.
vscode-containers.debug.attach.processId: The process id to attach to. Use "${command:pickProcess}" to get a list of running processes to attach to. If 'processId' used, 'processName' should not be used.
The process id to attach to. Use "${command:pickProcess}" to get a list of running processes to attach to. If 'processId' used, 'processName' should not be used.
vscode-containers.debug.attach.platform: The target platform for the application.

The path for the debugger in the target container, for example `/remote_debugger/vsdbg`.

vscode-containers.config.containers.cont: The property to use to group containers in Containers view: ContainerId, ContainerName, CreatedTime, FullTag, ImageId, Networks, Ports, Registry, RegistryAndPath, Repository, RepositoryName, RepositoryNameShort, RepositoryNameAndTag, State, Status, Tag, or None
The items will be grouped by the value of this container label (e.g. `com.microsoft.created-by`)

Any secondary properties to display for a container (an array). Possible elements include: ContainerId, ContainerName, CreatedTime, FullTag, ImageId, Networks, Ports, Registry, RegistryAndPath, Repository, RepositoryName, RepositoryNameShort, RepositoryNameAndTag, State, Status, and Tag

The primary property to display for a container: ContainerId, ContainerName, CreatedTime, FullTag, ImageId, Networks, Ports, Registry, RegistryAndPath, Repository, RepositoryName, RepositoryNameShort, RepositoryNameAndTag, State, Status, or Tag
The property to use to sort containers in the Containers view: CreatedTime or Label
Any secondary properties to display for a Docker context (an array). Possible elements include: Name, Description and DockerEndpoint
The primary property to display for a Docker context: Name, Description or DockerEndpoint
Show current Docker context in the status bar
vscode-containers.config.containers.imag: The property to use to group images in Container Images view: CreatedTime, FullTag, ImageId, None, Registry, RegistryAndPath, Repository, RepositoryName, RepositoryNameShort, RepositoryNameAndTag, or Tag

The primary property to display for a image: CreatedTime, FullTag, ImageId, Registry, RegistryAndPath, Repository, RepositoryName, RepositoryNameShort, RepositoryNameAndTag, Tag, or Size
The property to use to sort images in Container Images view: CreatedTime, Label, or Size
Check for outdated base images once per Visual Studio Code session
vscode-containers.config.containers.netw: The property to use to group networks in Container Networks view: CreatedTime, NetworkDriver, NetworkId, NetworkName, or None
Any secondary properties to display for a container network (an array). Possible elements include CreatedTime, NetworkDriver, NetworkId, and NetworkName
The primary property to display for a container network: CreatedTime, NetworkDriver, NetworkId, or NetworkName
The property to use to sort networks in Container Networks view: CreatedTime or Label

vscode-containers.config.containers.volu: The property to use to group volumes in Container Volumes view: CreatedTime, VolumeName, or None
Any secondary properties to display for a container volume (an array). Possible values include CreatedTime and VolumeName
The primary property to display for a container volume: CreatedTime or VolumeName
The property to use to sort volumes in the Container Volumes view: CreatedTime or Label
vscode-containers.config.containers.imag: Build context PATH to pass to container build command.
vscode-containers.config.containers.trun: Set to true to truncate long image and container registry paths in Container Images view
Maximum length of a registry paths displayed in Container Images view, including ellipsis. The truncateLongRegistryPaths setting must be set to true for truncateMaxLength setting to be effective.
vscode-containers.config.containers.envi: Environment variables that will be applied to all VS Code terminals and to all background processes started by the Container Tools extension. Use for variables like `DOCKER_HOST`, etc.
vscode-containers.config.docker.language: Controls the diagnostic severity for the deprecated MAINTAINER instruction
Controls the diagnostic severity for flagging empty continuation lines found in instructions that span multiple lines
Controls the diagnostic severity for parser directives that are not written in lowercase
Controls the diagnostic severity for instructions that are not written in uppercase
Controls the diagnostic severity for flagging a Dockerfile with multiple CMD instructions
Controls the diagnostic severity for flagging a Dockerfile with multiple ENTRYPOINT instructions
Controls the diagnostic severity for flagging a Dockerfile with multiple HEALTHCHECK instructions
Controls the diagnostic severity for JSON instructions that are written incorrectly with single quotes
Controls the diagnostic severity for WORKDIR instructions that do not point to an absolute path
Controls whether the Dockerfile formatter should ignore instructions that span multiple lines when formatting
vscode-containers.config.containers.comp: Set to true to include --build option when compose command is invoked
Set to true to include --d (detached) option when compose command is invoked
vscode-containers.config.containers.show: Set to true to prompt to switch from "UI" extension mode to "Workspace" extension mode if an operation is not supported in UI mode.
vscode-containers.config.containers.scaf: The path to use for scaffolding templates.
vscode-containers.config.containers.cont: Command to use for container actions (e.g. `docker` command). If the executable path contains whitespace, it needs to be quoted appropriately. If unset, the extension will attempt to auto-detect the command to use.
vscode-containers.config.containers.comp: Command to use for compose actions (e.g. `docker-compose`, `docker compose`, etc. command). If the executable path contains whitespace, it needs to be quoted appropriately. If unset, the extension will attempt to auto-detect the command to use.
vscode-containers.config.containers.enab: Whether or not to enable the Compose Language Service. Changing requires a restart to take effect.
vscode-containers.config.containers.cont: Which container client to use. If not specified, Docker will be used. Changing requires a restart to take effect.
vscode-containers.config.containers.orch: Which container orchestrator client to use. If not specified, Docker Compose will be used. Changing requires a restart to take effect.
vscode-containers.config.deprecated: This setting has been deprecated and will be removed in a future release.

vscode-containers.workspaceTrust.descrip: Workspace must be trusted in order to perform relevant container actions.
vscode-containers.walkthrough.containers: Getting Started with Container Tools
Learn about Docker and the Container Tools extension for Visual Studio Code
Choose your Container Runtime

The Container Tools extension supports multiple container runtimes. Choose the one you want to use - you can change this anytime.
[Choose Container Runtime](command:vscode-containers.chooseContainerRuntime)
Open a Workspace Folder

Open a workspace folder to get started with Container Tools extension features.
[Open Folder](command:workbench.action.files.openFolder)

Open a workspace folder to get started with Container Tools extension features.
[Open Folder](command:workbench.action.files.openFileFolder)
Add Docker Files to Workspace

A Dockerfile contains the instructions to assemble an image containing your app and its dependencies. Using this image to run your app in a container creates a production-like, reproducible runtime environment.

IntelliSense support for authoring your Dockerfile is provided.
[Add Docker Files](command:vscode-containers.configure)
Build an Image

The Container Tools extension makes it simple to build your image.
[Build Image](command:vscode-containers.images.build)
Run a Container

You can run any image on your system including those you've built with a Dockerfile.
[Run Image](command:vscode-containers.images.run)
Use the Container Explorer

The Container Explorer makes it easy to manage, troubleshoot, and deploy containerized applications. The Container Explorer shows a number of container resources such as containers, images, volumes, networks, and container registries.

The right-click menu provides access to commonly used commands for each resource type.
[Open Container Explorer](command:vscode-containers.views.containers.focus)
Push an Image to a Container Registry

The Container Tools Extension allows you to push your container image to Docker Hub, Azure Container Registry and other registry providers.
[Push an Image](command:vscode-containers.images.push)
Deploy to Azure App Service

The Container Tools extension helps you deploy your containerized applications and take advantage of a fully-managed platform using Azure App Service. Prior to deployment, the image must be uploaded to either Azure Container Registry or Docker Hub.

After a successful deployment, select **Open Site** in the notification. Your container is running in Azure!
[Deploy](command:vscode-containers.registries.deployImageToAzure)
Learn More

Great job! You've now completed Getting Started with Container Tools. But don't stop here! There are plenty of ways to become more proficient building containerized applications using the Container Tools extension.

For example, you can [debug a container](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/containers/debug-common), or [run multiple containers](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/containers/docker-compose) at once using Docker Compose.

Check out our [documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/containers/overview) to make the most of the Container Tools extension for VS Code!
